Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Affordable remote cardiac monitoring device for improved firefighter safety outcomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve occupational safety and health outcomes within the fire service through translational research and development of an affordable wearable physiologic monitoring device. Nearly 50% of firefighter line of duty deaths are the result of sudden cardiovascular events and the societal costs of firefighter injuries are in the billions of dollars, yet many departments cannot afford the costs of implementing the firefighter monitoring programs. Therefore, the use of an affordable wearable which can gather, store and transmit physiological data in real-time has the potential to reduce fatalities, injuries and costs. The affordability of manufacturing the device is the major commercial innovation as it will extend the physiological monitoring capability to workers exposed to extreme environmental conditions such as firefighters, soldiers, chemical and biological lab technicians, and commercial drivers - groups that have not been able to afford the cost of longitudinal and/or real-time physiological monitoring and predictive diagnostics. The affordability of the device will enable researchers to further scientific knowledge correlating the interrelationship between experimental physiological monitoring and field-based data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
AvidCor NSF Phase I Project Outcomes Report:

The goal of AvidCor’s NSF-SBIR Phase I grant was to continue the development of a “computational means for utilizing data that is obtained in real-time from a low cost, medical grade cardiac monitoring device that is suitable to be used in environments where firefighters work…” and to develop and test a prototype of a wearable vital monitoring device optimized for use by firefighters and other in the fire protection services. 

AvidCor was able to develop and test two prototypes of the device in collaboration with sub-awardees at Colorado State University. These trials were divided into two stages and tested biometric data recording at three levels of user activity; resting, walking, and running. As a control, an industry standard 12-lead EKG device was used to record cardiac data. 

Stage 1 trials were conducted with the first prototype, and upon receiving feedback from CSU, further, development was conducted to take into account needs discovered over the course of the trials. 

Stage 2 trials were conducted using the revised prototype, which featured upgrades to the device ergonomics, sensors, and improvements to the software and machine learning algorithms used to process the biometric data. 

See Figure 1: Data analysis in Prototype 1 & 2

Results of the Stage 2 trial were: improved filtering methods, improved analytic algorithms, and an improved UI/UX experience for users based upon the feedback from CSU. Feedback from researchers at CSU led us to begin the development of a comprehensive health and safety monitoring platform. Analysis of the results demonstrated that there was no statistically significant difference between the standard 12-lead EKG readings and the readings from the AvidCor prototype. Statistical analysis revealed p-values < 0.01 for R to R intervals and p-values < 0.0005 for HR when the device was compared to the standard 12-lead EKG.

Outcomes from the Phase I development and testing stages included:

?     Presentations & attendance at four industry-leading conferences and Symposiums:

  • Human-Computer International 2018 - Design, User Experience, and Usability. Las Vegas, NV.
  • SIGDOC ‘17 - Proceedings of the 35th International Conference on the Design of Communication (SIGDOC). Halifax, Nova Scotia.
  • Futures of Work & Learning in the US: Fire Service Education & Training - Hosted by International Society of Fire Service Instructors. Ft. Collins, CO.
  • Firefighter Physiological Monitoring Technology Summit - Hosted by the National Fallen Firefighter Foundation, and Science Medicine And Research & Technology for Emergency Responders (SMARTER). Washington, DC.

?     Technological innovations, including software and computational methods development and optimization.

  • Computational methods – machine learning algorithms and filter optimization, optimized for use by firefighters.
  • AvidCor mobile app for iOS & Android, which allows for easy upload and review of data.
  • Cloud-based WebApp and associated computational methods, for users, clinicians, and administrators/safety officers.
  • Wearable device prototypes which will serve as a basis for further research & development.

The impact of this project extends beyond the immediate field of application and will allow for further investigation of topics relating to firefighter health and safety outcomes. The information collected over the course of the trials not only provided data on the accuracy and effectiveness of the device but also provided data for further research in the fields of exercise physiology, cardiology, and public health. The dialogue this project has created between researchers and stakeholders within the fire services has laid the groundwork for future collaboration revolving around the reduction of occupational risk and hazard for firefighters, from a clinical, environmental and public health perspective.
